# Chapter 2 

> Political parties accept alliance with potential anchoring groups only wehn winning coalitions inside those parties see the path to ongoing electoral majority with the anchoring group incorporated. 

## Chapter 3

A group of labor leaders break from AFL's non-partisan commitments, forming the CIO, which help elect democrats, starting with FDR in 1936.

## Chapter 4 

New Right entrepreneurs, Richard Viguerie and Paul Weyrich, organize evangelicals into Moral Majority in 1979, connecting religion to electoral politics and helping to elect Reagan in 1980.

## Chapter 5 

## Populism 

Reshaped politics and the terrain of conflict for both parties. 

However, neither fully embraced the Populists' challenge to corporate capitalism. 

The remnants of the movement merged with the Democrats in 1896. 

## The Antiwar movement 

- Contributed to the change in public attitude toward war in Vietnam. 

- But anti-war Senator George McGovern won the presidential nomination in 1972 only after the movement had splintered and lacked power to challenge policies of American imperialism

PART II 

When movement energy dissipates, movement focuse on maintaining their organizations and protexting their policy victories. 

Movements stay in the party coalition as long as they can trade  votes and resources for policy influence.
